facts.text: Criminal Appeals Nos. 58 and 87 of 1953 were heard by the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPFLLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeals Nos. 58 and 87 of 1953. Appeal by Special Leave

facts.text: Appeal by Special Leave granted by the Supreme Court on the 30th June, 1953 for Criminal Appeal No. 58 from the Judgment and Order dated the 25th April, 1953 of the Judicial Commissioner at Ajmer.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave granted by- the Supreme Court on the 30th June, 1953, from the Judgment and Order dated the 25th April, 1953, of the Court of the Judicial Commissioner at Ajmer in Criminal Appeal No. 13 of 1953

facts.text: Appeal by Special Leave granted by the Supreme Court on the 27th October, 1953 for Criminal Appeal No. 87 from the Judgment and Order dated the 25th April, 1953 of the Judicial Commissioner at Ajmer.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by Special Leave granted by the Supreme Court on the 27th October, 1953, from the Judgment and Order dated the 25th April, 1953, of the Court of the Judicial Commissioner at Ajmer in Criminal Appeals Nos. 14 and 15 of 1953

facts.text: Judgment and Order dated the 18th March, 1953 of the Sessions Judge at Ajmer in Sessions Trial No. 1 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: and Criminal Reference No. 19 of 1953 arising out of the Judgment and Order dated the 18th March, 1953, of the Court of the Sessions Judge at Ajmer in Sessions Trial No. 1 of 1953.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered on 1954 March 17 by MAHAJAN C.J.

anchor.surface_text: 1954. March 17. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by MAHAJAN C.J.-Criminal Appeals Nos. 58 and 87 of 1953 relate to the same occurrence,

facts.text: On the 16th of July, 1952, Mangilal deceased, partner of firm Rambhajan Mangilal of Bijainagar, received by express delivery post a letter Exhibit P-5.

anchor.surface_text: On the 16th of July, 1952, Mangilal deceased, partner of firm Rambhajan Mangilal of Bijainagar, received by express delivery post a letter Exhibit P-5 in a closed cover Exhibit P-6.

facts.text: The letter purported to have been sent by Bhayankar Daku Dal demanding payment of Rs. 5,000 at 6-30 p.m. on the 17th of July at the crossing near the 27th milestone on the Ajmer-Bijainagar road.

anchor.surface_text: This letter was actually delivered to, Mangilals son Laduram who, on reading it, found that it purported to have been sent by Bhayankar Daku Dal demanding payment of Rs. 5,000 at 6-30 p.m. on the 17th of July at the -crossing near the 27th milestone

facts.text: Laduram took the original letter with the envelope to his uncle Ramjas at Ajmer and both saw the Superintendent of Police and gave him the letter and asked for protection.

anchor.surface_text: Laduram took the .original letter with the envelope to his uncle Ramjas at Ajmer and both of them saw the Superintendent of Police and gave him the letter and the envelope and asked for immediate protection and investigation.

facts.text: Superintendent of Police took no action.

anchor.surface_text: The Superintendent of Police, however, took noaction in this behalf.

facts.text: On the 17th of July about 9-30 p.m. Mangilal was shot dead by a person dressed in blue suit using a Mauser pistol while sitting at his shop.

anchor.surface_text: On the 17th of July about 9-30 p.m. when he was sitting at his shop and his munim Gajanand was writing the accounts two persons came from the neighbouring street.

facts.text: Two persons came: one dressed in khaki suit, the other in blue suit. Man in blue demanded reply to letter, man in khaki took Mangilal's gun from wall.

anchor.surface_text: One of them was dressed in a khaki suit and the other in a blue suit. The man in blue demanded from Mangilal a reply to the letter, while the man in khaki entered the shop and removed Mangilals gun

facts.text: First information report lodged by Nand Lal P.W.1 immediately after at 9-45 p.m.

anchor.surface_text: Mangilal died shortly afterwards. The first information report was lodged by Nand Lal  P. W.1  immediately after the occurrence at 9-45 p.m.

facts.text: Prosecution charged four persons: Hem Raj, Hukum Singh, Milap Singh and Abdul Hakim with conspiracy.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution challaned four persons, viz., Hem Raj, appellant in Criminal Appeal No. 58 of 1953, Hukum Singh, respondent in Criminal Appeal No. 87 of 1953, Milap Singh and Abdul Hakim.

facts.text: Hem Raj and Hukum Singh arrested on evening of 26th July 1952 at Bijainagar, sent to jail on 28th July 1952.

anchor.surface_text: It was alleged that all the four of them had acted in conspiracy and realised, money from rich persons through threatening letters and in pursuance of the conspiracy Exhibit P-5 was sent. Hem Raj and Hukum Singh were arrested

facts.text: Hem Raj made a confession on 30th July 1952 before a Magistrate in jail.

anchor.surface_text: Hem Raj and Hukum Singh were arrested on the evening of the 26th July at Bijainagar and were sent to jail on the 28th of July, 1952. On the 30th of July, 1952, Hem Raj made a confession

facts.text: Confession retracted by Hem Raj on 5th September 1952 before committing Magistrate.

anchor.surface_text: On the 30th of July, 1952, Hem Raj made a confession in jail before a Magistrate. On the 5th of September, 1952, at the first hearing of the case before the committing Magistrate,

facts.text: Sessions Judge convicted Hem Raj and Hukum Singh, acquitted Milap Singh and Abdul Hakim.

anchor.surface_text: All the accused persons denied the charge. Milap Singh and Abdul Hakim were acquitted by the learned Sessions Judge who how- ever convicted Hem Raj and Hukum Singh

facts.text: Judicial Commissioner allowed Hukum Singh's appeal, dismissed Hem Raj's appeal.

anchor.surface_text: Hem Raj and Hukum Singh appealed to the Judicial 1137 Commissioner at Ajmer. Hukum Singhs appeal was allowed but that of Hem Raj was dismissed.

facts.text: Hem Raj claimed confession was inadmissible, not voluntary, preceded by inducement.

anchor.surface_text: Dr. Tek Chand for Hem Raj raised three points before us That the confession was inadmissible in evidence, the prosecution having failed to establish affirmatively that it was free and voluntary

facts.text: Court found confession voluntary, corroborated in material particulars.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judicial Commissioner as well as the, learned Sessions Judge considered all these contentions and negatived them and there were valid reasons for doing so.

facts.text: Confession made two days after lodged in jail, on 30th July 1952.

anchor.surface_text: As regards the voluntary nature of the confession, the significant fact is that the confession was made on the 30th of July, that is, two days after Hem Raj had been lodged in jail,

facts.text: Gajanand (PW 34) eye-witness deposed man in blue fired the shot.

anchor.surface_text: W. 34, Gajanand, an eye.witness of the occurrence, deposed that the man in blue had the pistol and fired the fatal shot.

facts.text: Articles recovered from Hem Raj's house on 18th July 1952: hat, mask, bush shirt, pistol.

anchor.surface_text: On the 18th of July, 1952, certain articles were recovered from Hem Rajas house-a hat, a mask., a bush shirt and a pistol.

facts.text: Other items recovered from Hem Raj's house on 25th July 1952.

anchor.surface_text: On the 25th July, 1952, certain other items were admittedly recovered from Hem Rajas house and these also corroborate the confession.

facts.text: Recoveries from roof of Bansilal's shop on 27th July 1952: revolver and cartridges.

anchor.surface_text: Then Certain recoveries were made, as stated in the confession, from the roof of Bansilals shop on 27th of July, 1952. These were a revolver and a number of cartridges.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld conviction of Hem Raj under section 302/34 IPC and 386 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that the evidence in conjunction with the confession satisfactorily establishes the charge under section 302/ 34, Indian Penal ,Code, against Hem Raja and also satisfactorily ves the offence under section 386, Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld acquittal of Hukum Singh, evidence insufficient.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion, that the learned Judicial Commissioner was perfectly right in holding that this evidence by itself was insufficient to uphold his conviction

facts.text: Mangilal was partner of firm Rambhajan Mangilal of Bijainagar.

anchor.surface_text: Mangilal deceased, partner of firm Rambhajan Mangilal of Bijainagar, received by express delivery post a letter

facts.text: Letter delivered to Mangilal's son Laduram.

anchor.surface_text: This letter was actually delivered to, Mangilals son Laduram who, on reading it, found that it

facts.text: Assailants threw Mauser pistol and khaki clothes on the way after murder.

anchor.surface_text: The two assailants then ran away. On the way they threw the Mauser pistol and khaki clothes in the street at a short distance from the shop.

facts.text: Hem Raj runs a cycle shop in Bijainagar.

anchor.surface_text: He is not a rustic but runs a cycle shop in Bijainagar.

facts.text: Hukum Singh declined to confess when Magistrate approached him.

anchor.surface_text: It is noteworthy that Hukum Singh was similarly situated and about whom an application had been made that he was willing to confess. When , the Magistrate approached him

arguments.claim: Neither appeal satisfies the test for interference under Article 136

anchor.surface_text: The question for consideration is whether this test is satisfied in either of these two appeals. After hearing the learned counsel. .in both the appeals we are satisfied that none of them raise any questions which fall within the rule enunciated above.

holdings.text: Neither of the appeals satisfies the test for interference under Article 136 of the Constitution as no exceptional circumstances exist warranting review of the lower courts' decisions.

anchor.surface_text: The question for consideration is whether this test is satisfied in either of these two appeals. After hearing the learned counsel. .in both the appeals we are satisfied that none of them raise any questions which fall within the rule enunciated above.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Application of established Art. 136 standards: no substantial grave injustice or sufficient gravity shown; special leave admission does not permit full re-appreciation of facts.

holdings.text: The confession made by Hem Raj was voluntary, as confirmed by concurrent findings of lower courts with no grounds to interfere.

anchor.surface_text: On the question whether the confession was voluntary, there are concurrent findings of the courts below and there are no grounds for going behind these findings.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Made in jail after 36 hours free from police influence; accused literate; no timely retraction; magistrate warnings complied; detailed content impossible to tutor; allegations of inducement/threats unsupported.

holdings.text: The confession is corroborated in material particulars by independent evidence.

anchor.surface_text: On the question whether material particulars of the confession have been corroborated, there are again concurrent findings. All the arguments addressed to us relate to the re-appreciation

holdings.reasoning_summary: Eyewitness testimony on shooter and clothes; recoveries of hat, mask, shirt, pistol, socks, shorts, torch, revolver, cartridges, gun case matching confession details; concurrent findings endorsed.

holdings.text: Evidence in conjunction with the corroborated confession establishes Hem Raj's guilt under Sections 302/34 and 386 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that the evidence in conjunction with the confession satisfactorily establishes the charge under section 302/ 34, Indian Penal Code, against Hem Raj and also satisfactorily proves the offence under section 386, Indian Penal Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Confession + eyewitness + recoveries + inference Hem Raj posted threat letter prove murder with common intention and extortion.

holdings.text: Evidence against Hukum Singh is insufficient to uphold conviction; he is entitled to benefit of doubt on both charges.

anchor.surface_text: We are of the opinion, that the learned Judicial Commissioner was perfectly right in holding that this evidence by itself was insufficient to uphold his conviction and that Hukum Singh was entitled to the benefit of the doubt

holdings.reasoning_summary: Key, latch breaking, association with Hem Raj, handwriting not enough alone; cannot use co-accused confession substantively; no interference with acquittal justified.

holdings.text: A confession can be corroborated by evidence or facts already in police possession before the confession; not limited to new discoveries post-confession.

anchor.surface_text: The contention therefore that evidence in possession of the police before the confession was made, cannot be used to corroborate the confession, must be repelled.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Mata Din (value, not mode of corroboration); confessions during trial usable with prior evidence; police lacked some details like cartridges, letter writer, Mauser pistol.

holdings.text: Inference that Hem Raj posted the threatening letter Exhibit P-5 is reasonable given he was in Beawar on the posting date.

anchor.surface_text: We think that the criticism is not valid and the inference drawn in the circumstances of this case by the courts below could not be said to be unreasonable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Circumstantial evidence supports lower courts' conclusion; criticism of mere presence rejected as inference not unreasonable.

holdings.text: No material justifies interference with Hukum Singh's acquittal in special leave appeal.

anchor.surface_text: There is hardly any material on the record to justify our interference with an order of acquittal in an appeal by special leave.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Art 136 restraint applies; evidence insufficient as per lower appellate court.

anchor.surface_text: Queen v. Thompson 1 , in which it had been emphasized that in order that evidence of a companyfession by a prisoner may be admissible, it must be affirmatively proved that such companyfession was free and voluntary and that it was number preceded by any inducement to the prisoner to make a statement held out by a person, in authority, or that it was number made until after such inducement had clearly been removed-. The  1  1893 2 Q.B 12.

precedents.cited_proposition: in order that evidence of a companyfession by a prisoner may be admissible, it must be affirmatively proved that such companyfession was free and voluntary and that it was number preceded by any inducement to the prisoner to make a statement held out by a person in authority, or that it was number made until after such inducement had clearly been removed

anchor.surface_text: Mata Din v. The Emperor 1 , wherein it was observed that a true companyfession made by a person who takes part in a murder invariably adds something to the knowledge already possessed by the investigating officer and that is the greatest test of its truth. In our opinion, the companytention raised by the learned companynsel is number were founded.

precedents.cited_proposition: a true companyfession made by a person who takes part in a murder invariably adds something to the knowledge already possessed by the investigating officer and that is the greatest test of its truth

anchor.surface_text: The decision in Mata Dins case 1 does number support the view companytended for. That decision merely companycerns itself with the value of a companyfession and does number relate to the nature and character of evidence that can be led to companyroborate it. It does number lay down the proposition that a companyfession cannot be companyroborated by use of materials already in possession of the police.

precedents.cited_proposition: concerns the value of a confession

anchor.surface_text: After hearing the learned companynsel. .in both the appeals we are satisfied that numbere of them raise any questions which fall within the rule enunciated above.

outcome.relief_summary: Both appeals dismissed. No interference with lower courts' decisions. Hem Raj's conviction under sections 302/34 and 386 IPC upheld. Hukum Singh's acquittal upheld.
